loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth is a 47-year-old married woman with 2 children. She and her husband are both farmers. While her husband mainly manages their rice farm, she also makes sure to help keep it productive. She also takes good care of their children. Lilibeth always wishes for her family to have good health.

Lilibeth's loan will be used to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Ma. Fe

texts.en:
48-year-old Ma. Fe is a married woman living in the town of Banga, South Cotabato. She has 3 children aged 25, 15 and 8.

Ma. Fe is a farmer. She has been growing rice for 11 years and she rents a stall at the market to sell her harvest. She works hard to help provide for and improve the living conditions of her family

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is a  37-year-old married man with six children living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda.  He dreams of educating his children to attain a degree.

For five years he has been operating a drugstore.  With his savings, he has been able to pay school fees for his children.  He faces a challenge of high taxes levied on him.  His desire is to own a pharmacy.   Vincent is seeking the loan to buy drugs to sell.

loans.use: to buy drugs to sell at his drugstore

loans.name: Fernando

texts.en:
Fernando J. is from the village of Tuod, Manticao, Misamis Oriental. He is 52 years old and married, with 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Fernando sells seafood products including fish like sardines and milkfish. Fernando has been engaged in his business for more than 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Fernando joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fernando has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Fernando is requesting his second loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell, such as mackerel and sardines. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell such as mackerel and sardines

loans.name: Eldie

texts.en:
Eldie P. is from the village of Tuod, Manticao, Misamis Oriental. He is 52 years old. Eldie is a widower. To make a living, he owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling snack foods, canned goods, biscuits and beverages in the local community. He also occasionally provides habal-habal or motorela (motorcycle transportation) services. Eldie has been engaged in his business for over thirty-one years and earns approximately $150 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Eldie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Eldie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This will be his 5th loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam is a forty-five-year-old married woman living in her own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. She is the mother of eight children and her desire is to educate them. She has been farming for ten years and the proceeds have enabled her to provide the basics for the family. She has a challenge of limited funds and her desire is to become a commercial farmer. Mariam intends to use the loan to grow maize.

loans.use: to grow maize.

loans.name: Marriane

texts.en:
Marriane is 35 years old, married and has five children. Her oldest child is 12 years old.

Marriane is a farmer. She has been growing rice and corn for eleven years now. She sells her harvest to the market. Marriane works hard for her family. She wants her children to finish college and have bright futures.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce would like a loan to buy fuel to transport firewood.  Five years back she started supplying firewood to individuals and later expanded to supplying companies.  Her business gets low during rainy seasons. She wants to educate her children and hopes to change to operating a hardware shop after acquiring enough start up capital.  Joyce needs the loan to transport firewood to sell in different areas.

loans.use: to buy fuel to transport firewood to sell in different areas

loans.name: Hamisi

texts.en:
Hamisi is married to a businesswoman and they have six children, all of whom graduated from school. They live in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For over twenty years, he has operated a fruit and vegetable selling business, selling at the market to his neighbors and passersby. With the 40,000 KES he is requesting, he wants to purchase sacks of vegetables and fruits for resale. He dreams of establishing a retail shop in the future.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of vegetables and fruits for resale.

loans.name: Rut

texts.en:
Ruth is a 35-year-old single woman who lives in Kupang. She has been running a beauty salon business since 2009. Prior to running her own business, Ruth worked in a beauty salon in Kupang for about two years. In 2006, she was entrusted with managing a beauty salon owned by her aunt, and did so until the beginning of 2009. From there, Ruth wanted to open her own business and so she did, with her little savings. 
 
She experienced ups and downs while running her business. Lack of equipment and availability of employees to assist her in running the business have become her greatest challenges. She realizes that the income generated from the business depends on the number of customers she has. 

Ruth really wants to improve her business to satisfy her customers. In order to do so, she is requesting a loan of 4,000,000 IDR from TLM to buy additional equipment such as a hair flatiron for her salon. She is hoping that her loan application will be approved.

loans.use: to buy additional equipment such as a hair flatiron

loans.name: Constancia

texts.en:
Constancia D. C. is from the village of Acmac, Iligan City. She is 54 years old. Constancia is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products including fresh mackerel and milk fish and different kinds of dried fish in the local community. Constancia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Constancia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Constancia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fresh and dried fish to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fresh and dried fish to sell

location.town: Acmac, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is a married woman with one child. She is a farmer and has been growing rice and corn crops for five years. She earns about $125 per month from this farming.

Mary Ann needs fertilizers and seeds, so she applied for a loan of 8,000 PHP from CEVI, a KIVA partner. She hopes for this loan to help improve her harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
26-year-old Moses M. has been in a food sales business for the last five years. Staple foods such as bananas, cassava, maize and rice are what he has been selling, for the most part. His operating base is in Ryabatenga-Ibanda. 

This young, hardworking lad, who is also a father to two high-spirited kids, says he set forth in this business after he sold off some of his acres of land. Before that, he was doing mostly modest retailing and also moonlighted as a bartender. He says this business generates about $85 a month. 

Moses is requesting this loan to purchase land so that he can grow crops like bananas and maize on a large scale.

loans.use: to purchase land to grow crops like bananas and maize on a large scale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Merita

texts.en:
Merita is a married woman who lives in the town of Banga, South Cotabato, with her family. She is 54 years old and has two children, aged 19 and 23.

Merita is a rice farmer and hog raiser. She prepares her land well for planting rice crops. She also makes sure the pigs she raises are healthy. Merita sells her rice and pigs to the market. This has been her family's source of income for quite some time now.

Merita's loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and feeds.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and feeds

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma C. is from the village of Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old. Emma is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Emma buys and raises pigs for sale. Emma has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2007, Emma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Emma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Emma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred B., 35, is a married woman with two children. Her oldest child is 10 years old. Both of her children go to school. Mildred does her best to sustain their education.

Mildred is a farmer and has been growing rice for more than four years now. She earns by selling her harvest to the market. 

She currently needs fertilizers and other farm inputs. Mildred requested a loan that she can use to fund her farm. Mildred hopes to have an increased harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe T. is from the village of Suarez, Iligan City. She is 30 years old. Fe is married and has four school-aged children. 

To make a living, Fe owns and operates a  food stall, making and selling a variety of viands like pork and chicken adobo in the local community. She also makes and sells sausage or longganisa. Fe has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Fe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Fe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional ingredients and for working capital. 

Fe is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase ingredients like meats, vegetables and spices. This will be the second loan taken out by Fe from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients like meats, vegetables and spices

location.town: Suarez, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane N. is a married woman with two school going-children. They own a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

For the past four yeas, she has operated a charcoal-selling business. She sells from her home to her neighbors and friends. As another source of income, Jane sells second-hand clothes, and that helps her meet her family's daily needs.

She decided to join Yehu microfinance because of its good reputation. With the KES 60,000 she is requesting, she wants to purchase 20 bags of charcoal to sell. 

She dreams of establishing rental houses in the future.

loans.use: to purchase 20 bags of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Janith

texts.en:
Janith P. is from the village of Tuod, Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 26 years old. Janith is married and has two school-aged children. 

To make a living, Janith buys and sells coconuts for copra (dried coconut meat used for oil production) and coco charcoals in the local community. Janith has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Janith joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Janith has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Janith is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional coconuts and charcoal to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Janith from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional coconuts and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Flora

texts.ru:
Флора Ан родилась в 1946 году в селе Кара-Тюпе (Нижнечерчекском районе,  Республика Узбекистан). Ей 65 лет. Мама Флоры умерла, когда девочке было 2 года и ее воспитанием занималась мачеха.  Закончив 9 классов средней школы, Флора начала заниматься полеводством в качестве луковода в колхозе села Кара-Тюпе и  через два года вышла замуж  за односельчанина  Платона. Из-за нехватки поливной воды в Узбекистане,  Флора вместе с мужем и 3-мя малолетними детьми переехала в Кыргызскую Республику в с. Красная Речка. Дела на новом месте шли хорошо, Флора и Платон арендовали землю, выращивали лук, бахчевые культуры и томаты и за три года нелегкого  труда, им удалось скопить денег на собственный дом.  В 1992 году  Флора вместе с мужем попытались уехать в Россию на заработки, но много заработать не удалось и помыкавшись по углам, они вернулись в Кыргызстан. Здесь они опять арендовали землю, и занялись привычным для себя делом - полеводством. Так как Флора с мужем с раннего возраста  начали работать и не смогли продолжить обучение, они сделали все возможное, чтобы дать своим 2 дочерям и сыну  хорошее образование в университетах страны. В 2005 году, Флора впервые, услышав от знакомых о Компании «Бай-Тушум и Партнеры», обратилась за своим первым кредитом. Уже более шести лет она продолжает работать с Компанией и каждую весну, готовясь к поливным работам, Флора обращается за кредитом для приобретения семян, удобрений и ГСМ. Кроме того,  Флора занимается животноводством и содержит в хозяйстве корову, также планирует в ближайшем будущем увеличить свое поголовье до 3 голов. Флора планирует взять кредит в сумме 60,000 сом (KGS) для приобретения семян и удобрений для посева и обработки земли. 
Около 2 лет назад Флора потеряла сына – он умер от онкологического заболевания, но дочери и внуки стали ее поддержкой и опорой для нее.  Флора не может сидеть без дела и делает все для того, чтобы сделать жизнь ее семьи благополучной и достойной. 
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance Institutions in KyrgyzstA.. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urbA. areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.
texts.en:
Flora A. was born in 1946 in the village of Kara-Tule (Nizhnechechersk Region, the Republic of UzbekistA.). She is 65 years old. Flora’s mother’s died when she was two years old, and she was brought up by a stepmother. After finishing nine years of secondary school, Flora  started working as a farmer, growing onions at the communal farm of the Kara-Tule Village. Two years later, she married Platon, a mA. from her village. Due to shortage of irrigation water in UzbekistA., Flora together with her husband and three young children moved to KyrgyzstA., to the village of Krasnaya Rechka. 

Things were going well at their new home. Flora and Platon took a lease out on a land plot and grew onions, tomatoes, melons etc. After three years of hard work, they managed to put enough money aside to buy their own house. In 1992, Flora and her husband had the idea of  going to Russia as migrant workers, but they weren’t able to earn much. After a lot of trials and lack of permanent living quarters, they returned   to KyrgystA.. Here again they leased land and continued to do the work they are used to—farming. Since Flora and her husband started working early and did not have a chance to continue their education, they did everything in their power to enable their two daughters and son to receive good university education. In 2005, having first heard of the Bai-Tushum and Partners organization, Flora requested her first loA.. She has been collaborating with this company for over six years. Every spring, in preparation for irrigation works, she requests credit to purchase seeds, fertilizers and fuel. In addition, she raises livestock. She keeps a cow and plans to have 3 cows in total in the future. Flora plans to take out a loA. in the amount of 60,000 KGS to purchase seeds and fertilizers for planting and preparing her soil. 

About two years ago Flora lost her son, who died from cancer, but her daughters and grandchildren became her  source of support and help. Flora cA.’t remain idle and does all she cA. in order to help  offer her family a good and dignified   life.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther L. is from the village of Villa Verde, Iligan City. She is 54 years old. Esther is married and has four adult children. 

To make a living, Esther runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, biscuits and beverages in the local community. Esther has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Esther joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Esther has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Esther is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This will be the third loan taken out by Esther from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods

location.town: Villaverde, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy A. is from the village of Calangahan, Iligan City. She is 30 years old. Nancy is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she sells coconut shell and wood charcoals in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $250 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Nancy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Nancy is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional charcoals to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is married with three children, all of whom attend school. They live in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her husband is employed and he contributes to his family's basic needs with his income. For the past five years, Mary has operated a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. 

Mary’s greatest monthly expenses are school fees for her children and house rent. She dreams of supplying charcoal to retailers in the future. With the loan she is requesting she wants to purchase 50 sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu because of no collateral required and its simplicity to join.

loans.use: to purchase 50 sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Marquita

texts.en:
Marquita V. is from the village of Kanitoan, Initao, Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old. Marquita is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, biscuits and beverages in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $100 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marquita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Marquita is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim lives in a small city of Pakistan called Borewala. Borewala is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and is known for its wood works, like furniture. Her house contains two rooms and she has been living in it with her family for the past twelve years. She is 45 years old, married to M. H. and has two sons. Her elder son sells fruits, while the younger one operates a donkey cart and provides loading services to his clients.  

Her husband is a rickshaw driver and provides transport services to passengers and school children. Shamim has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, because her husband needs to repair his rickshaw. Due to excessive usage, its engine has started creating problems and needs repair urgently. He has been operating his transport business for the past ten years and Shamim is confident that after repairing his rickshaw, her husband will be able to continue his work and earn better profits.

loans.use: to repair a rickshaw

loans.name: Nelita

texts.en:
Nelita, who is 62 years old, is a married woman with ten children. Nelita said that she and her husband work hard to provide for their big family.

Nelita makes a living growing and selling rice. She and her husband, who are both farmers, till their land and prepare it well for planting. Nelita wishes to have better living conditions.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Sointa

texts.en:
Sointa E. K. is age 39, married, and has four children together with her husband. She is a farmer who plants cash crops. She has been farming for the last six years with a monthly profit of Kshs 5,000. 

She learned about KADET from our credit officers and joined. She has applied for her first loan which she plans to use to purchase fertilizers, maize seeds and chemicals for spraying. She hopes to use the profit generated from the loan to expand her farming. 

Her future dreams are to educate her children to the highest level. She is a hardworking woman who puts much effort into her work.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, maize seeds and chemicals for spraying.

loans.name: Isaie

texts.en: Isai is 64 years old, and he has eight children, ages 25 to 44. He owns a restaurant in which he sells African food and a shop in which he sells several items such as rice, cooking oil, Irish potatoes, etc. He is requesting a loan to buy more items to sell in his shop and more restaurant equipment. With the profits he plans to purchase more goods.

loans.use: to purchase restaurant equipment and items to sell in his shop.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian is a single mother with four children, all of whom attend school. They own a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and house rent bills. For the past four years, she has operated a clothes selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbors and passersby. 

With the 70,000 KES she wants to purchase bundles of clothes for resale. She dreams of establishing a retail shop in the future. Vivian joined Yehu microfinance because of its good reputation in the society.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of clothes for resale

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis lives with his family of eight, all adults, in his home village of Kisii in South Rift, Kenya. He has spent much of his life in farming and has two farmhands who help with the daily farming activities. He produces tea, bananas, peas and maize, which he delivers to the local market for sale. He gets pension benefits for additional income.  

Francis has requested a loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that a dairy cow acquired with the loan will improve his income and make their living standards better, especially with healthy nutrition from the consumption.

Francis points to inadequate capital and animal diseases as the main problems in farming in his area.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase building materials, iron sheets, timber and to pay labor.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy M. is a 35 year-old, single mother to three children. She has been a farmer in Nkareta-Narok, Kenya, for a period of two years, with an income of about Kshs 4,000 per month.

She found out about KADET through other women registered in her area.  She paid the previous loan successfully without hiccups, and this is her third loan from KADET LTD.  She wants to buy farm supplies such as seedlings and fertilizer. 

She hopes to grow different crops on her farm and improve the living standards of her family.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies, such as seedlings, fertilizer

loans.name: Noomali

texts.en:
Noomali E. L. is a very painstaking woman who practices farming in Nkareta-Narok, Kenya.  She has been in this business for over five years and earns a monthly income of KES 10,000. She is 29 years old and married to Maripet, who is also a farmer.  They have four children.

She is applying for her second loan and plans to use it to buy farm inputs. She intends to use the additional income from the proceeds of this loan to buy cattle for fattening and to pay her children's school fees. 

She hopes to develop her business and to be financially stable in the future

loans.use: to buy farm inputs

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Badenya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 33 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Fana, sous préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de bois de chauffe, de condiments, de parures et de parfums.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Badenya sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire. 
CHITAN D. compte acheter du bois de chauffe avec les charretiers de la ville presque quotidiennement. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 35 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The members of the Badenya solidarity group are all married women. They average 33 years of age and two children each, and they all live in extended traditional families in the town of Fana, sub-prefecture of Dioïla, in the Koulikoro region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They know one another as neighbors and through ties of kinship and friendship. They sell firewood, condiments, ornaments and perfumes. They are on their second group loan. 

Chitan D. plans to buy firewood from local carters almost every day. She conducts her sales daily from her home, for cash or credit, to a clientele composed of both men and women. 

She expects to earn an average monthly profit of 35,000 FCFA, which will be used to make loan repayments, pay contributions to social ceremonies, and reinvest in her business activity.

loans.use: to buy firewood

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 24 year old single man from Baalback, Ali has owned an Internet Cafe since 2008. This service is becoming popular, in his region, and he has to improve his business to adapt more customers. 

Ali is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the first time. In order to improve his business, he will increase the number of computers at his cafe, buying necessary UPS connection, and useful hardware. Ali is planning to expand his business and hopes to open a new branch of his business. He hopes to stay updated and attractive his clients. Many of his clients are friends, relatives and neighbors.

loans.use: To increase his computers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase his stock of batteries.

loans.name: Abd Al Ghene

texts.en:
Abd A. Ghene is a 68 year old married man living in Baalback with his wife and 4 children. 

Abd A. Ghene has baked Tannour bread (Khubz lubnani - also called Suri or Arabi) for 16 years. It is more widely known as pita bread and is baked stuck to a very hot pottery wall. He also works in selling oils as a second income. Abd A. Ghene is well known in his region especially for his tasty bread and good oil choice. He is requesting a loan from A. Majmoua for the first time, in order to increase his flour capitA. and to improve his oil business. Abd A. Ghene is an honest man. He is a hard worker and seeks secure & healthy living. He hopes to expand his business and open another branch in the future.

loans.use: To buy necessary flour to improve his business.

loans.name: Balimaya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Balimaya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 29 ans, 4 enfants et vivent majoritairement dans des familles nucléaires dans la ville de Fana, sous préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le                                                                                                                               
Les femmes du groupe Balimaya sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter de poissons et de condiments.                                                                         
ALIMATA C., la présidente du groupe,  compte acheter des poissons avec les revendeurs de la ville. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The members of the Balimaya group are all married women who average 29 years of age and four children each. They live mostly in nuclear families in the town of Fana, sub-prefecture of Dioïla, in the Koulikoro region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They know one another as neighbors and through ties of kinship and friendship. They are on their second group loan, which they will use to buy fish and condiments for resale.

Alimata C., president of the group, plans to buy fish from local resellers. She conducts her sales daily from her home and at the market, for cash or credit, to a customer base consisting of both men and women.

She expects to earn an average monthly profit of 25,000 FCFA, which she will use to make loan repayments, pay contributions to social ceremonies, and reinvest in her business activity.

loans.use: to buy fish

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les  six femmes du groupe Benkadi, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 29 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles nucléaires  dans la ville de Fana, sous préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de poissons, de tubercules, de l’huile d’arachide et des jus de boissons.                                                                                                                              
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire, le premier ayant été correctement remboursé.                                                                         
DJENEBA C. compte acheter une importante quantité d’igname avec les revendeurs de la place. Elle effectue ses ventes à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The six women of the group Benkadi are all married and average 29 years of age and three children all living in nuclear families in Fana City, sub-prefecture of Dioïla, Region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women know one another through ties of kinship, community, and friendship. They do commerce in fish, tubers, peanut oil, and juice drinks.

The group members of Benkadi are on their second solidarity loan. The first one was properly repaid.

Ms. DJENEBA C. plans on buying a major quantity of yams from local vendors. Accepting cash or credit, she makes her sales at the house and at the market. Her customer base is composed of women and men.

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA that will be used to make the loan payments and to help pay for societal ceremonies. The rest of the profits will be reinvested in her commerce.

loans.use: to buy yams

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Danaya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 34 ans, 4 enfants et vivent proportionnellement  dans des familles nucléaires et  traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Fana, sous préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le                                                                                                                                
Les femmes du groupe Danaya sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter d’habillements, de poissons, de banane et de bois de chauffe.                                                                         
MAMOU B. compte acheter beaucoup des bananes avec les revendeurs du marché. Elle effectue ses ventes sur place à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the group Danaya are all married and average 34 years of age and four children living proportionally in nuclear families and in traditional extended families, in Fana City, subprefecture of Dioïla, Region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women know one another through ties of kinship, community, and friendship. They are on their first solidarity loan, which will be used to buy clothing, fish, bananas, and firewood.

Ms. Mamou B. intends to use her loan to buy a lot of bananas from retailers at the market. Accepting cash or credit, she makes her sales locally out of her house and at the market. Her customer base is composed of women and men.

Mamou envisions making an average monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA that will be used to make the loan payments and to help pay for societal ceremonies. The rest of the profits will be reinvested in her commerce.

loans.use: to buy bananas

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq femmes du groupe Djekafo, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 25 ans, 4 enfants et vivent majoritairement dans des  traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Fana, sous préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce d’articles divers. Les femmes du groupe Djekafo sont à leur premier prêt solidaire                                                                                                                                                                                           
FATOUMATA C.  compte acheter des poissons avec les revendeurs du marché. Elle effectue ses ventes à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en: The five women of the Djekafo group are all married 25 year olds with four children each; they generally live in large extended families in the town of Fana, in the Dioïla municipality, in the Koulikoro region (the second largest administrative region in the Republic of Mali).  They met through family and friends. The women of the Djekafo group sell various products and are on their first loan. Fatoumata C. aims to purchase fish from the wholesalers at the market. She sells her goods from home and at the local market, and takes cash or credit sales from a customer base made up of men and women. She aims to generate an average monthly profit of 25,000 FCFA which will be used to pay back the balance of the loan, pay for social occasions, and to reinvest in the business.

loans.use: to purchase fish

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise is 39 years old and has seven children between 1 and 14 years old, all of whom are in school except the infant. Francoise’s husband is a driver, while Francoise owns a shop in which she sells rice, sugar, salt, cooking oil, soap, toothpaste, tea, books, and other items. 

She has had this business for eleven years, and she is requesting a loan in order to reinvest in her business by buying more sugar,rice,salt etc. With the profits, she wants to pay for her children’s school fees. Francoise hopes to grow her shop into more of a wholesale business.

loans.use: Buying more sugar,salt.,rice etc for her general store.

loans.name: Soutoura  (Prendre Soin De Soi-Même) Group

texts.fr:
Soutoura est un regroupement de femmes du quartier Madina Koura de la ville de Koutiala qui vivent ensemble dans le même quartier, dans des grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et coépouses. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 4 enfants.
Ce groupe Soutoura fait l’achat et la vente du bois de chauffe, d’habillements et  la transformation  des noix du néré en condiments alimentaires. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a un an, elles sont leur deuxième prêt et le prêt précèdent a été correctement remboursé. 
Djeneba O.  qui est un des membres fait l’achat la transformation des noix de néré en  Sounbala (un condiment alimentaire très apprécié par les Maliennes et dans la sous région)  Elle est très sollicitée car elle voyage avec son Sounbala  sur Bamako (capitale du Mali) et Gao.
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des sacs de noix de néré à Sikasso  à Dogonasso et  Zangasso. Elle vend le Sounbala en gros, en détail et au comptant à une clientèle essentiellement féminine à Bamako et à Gao.
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Soutoura comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 85 000FCFA chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Djeneba O.  elle,  compte réaliser 100 000 FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elles souhaitent diversifier  leurs activités.
texts.en:
Soutoura (meaning "taking care of oneself") is a group of women from the Madina Koura neighborhood in the city of Koutiala. They live in large traditional families with their husbands, children and co-spouses. They average 34 years of age, are married and have at least four children.

The group trades in firewood, clothing, and transformation of néré nuts into food condiments. To bolster their business, the members of the group decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, one year ago. They are now seeking their second loan, and the previous one was repaid without problem.

Djeneba O. is one of the members of the group. She buys néré nuts and transform them into Sounbala (a food condiment very much appreciated by Malian women, and in the subregion). She's very much in demand since she travels with her Sounbala to Bamako (the capital of Mali) and Gao.

She intends to use her part of the loan to buy sacks of néré nuts in Sikasso, in Dogonasso, and in Zangasso. She sells her Sounbala wholesale, retail and for cash, to a clientele comprising mostly women, in Bamako and Gao.

While the other members of the group intend to turn and average profit of XOF 85'000 (ca US$ 170) each during this loan cycle, Djeneba O. intends to reach XOF 100'000 (ca US$ 200).

In addition to repaying the loan, the women will use part of the profits to support the daily expenses of their families. They also wish to diversify their business.

loans.use: to buy and transform néré nuts

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is a married woman with one child who attends school. Her husband is a driver and he supports his family financially. They live in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. For the past three years, she has operated a tailoring business  in a shop where neighbors and passersby are her potential customers. 

With the 80,000 KES she is requesting, she wants to purchase a motorcycle and bundles of clothes for resale. Mwanasiti faces a major challenge of competition from those who sell similar products. She dreams of building her own house in the future. She decided to join Yehu because of its good reputation in the society.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle and bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en: Innocent is 31 years old and single. He sells home equipment, such as plates, glasses, spoons, etc. He is requesting a loan to buy more equipment in order to earn increased profits. With the profits and his savings he plans to build his own house.

loans.use: To purchase home equipment to sell

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Moses O. is single and lives in  a rental house that has electricity and piped water. He has operated a café for the past year; his customers are neighbors and passersby.  Moses is requesting a loan for 10,000 KES, which he will use to purchase maize flour, sugar and cooking oil. His greatest monthly expenses are rent and electricity bills. Moses dreams of being self-reliant and satisfying his customers' needs in the future. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to increase his business.

loans.use: To purchase maize flour, sugar, and cooking oil

loans.name: Chadia

texts.en:
Chadia is 38 years old, married, and has three children between 5 and 16 years old. 

Chadia sells peanuts, dried fish, and sunflower oil, and has done this business for 10 years, which has enabled her to develop herself and her family, while paying for her children’s school fees. 

With the loan, Chadia wants to reinvest in her business by buying more inventory for her business.

loans.use: to buy more peanuts, dried fish and sunflower oil

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 25 years old, unmarried, and without children. 

Alice sells traditional African fabrics called kitenge. She has done this business for five years. The business has allowed Alice to develop herself. 

After buying more fabrics, Alice hopes to use the profits to build her own house.

loans.use: to buy more fabrics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow and insurance

loans.name: Sinenjengo Group

texts.en:
Zibuyisile is 28 years old and married with one child, who is 7 years old. She also cares for two relatives. 

She runs a tuck shop in Nkandla in Kwa Z. Natal, South Africa. (Tuck shops are small corner stores where you can buy food, drink and other basics.) In the photo she is wearing a blue shirt and raising her hand.

She's been in this business for one and a half years and sells chips, drinks, and chicken pieces at her home. She also receives income from the government's child support grant. She says that the main challenges to her business are customers that buy on credit and fail to pay on time.

She requested this loan through Women’s Development Businesses to buy drinks, chicken pieces, and flour for making fat cookies. (Fat cookies are a kind of cake made from fried flour.) She hopes that the extra income from this loan will help her live a better life and build a house. In the future, she hopes to see her business grow in such a way that she can add more stock.

In her comments she adds that she does not have a shelter to sell her stock. She would like to know if WDB and Kiva can help her build her own shelter because now she is selling on the streets.

loans.use: to buy drink, chicken, and flour for making fat cookies

loans.name: Namunda

texts.en:
Namunda N. is a widow with three children, all of whom are grown. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. 

For the past two years, she has operated an open food market, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. 

Namunda faces a major challenge of seasonality. During the rainy cold season the availability of food for sale is high, while during the hot summer season the availability of food in the market is low. She dreams of becoming self-reliant in the future. 

With the KES 25,000 she wants to purchase bundles of maize flour, beans, rice and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of maize flour, beans, rice and cooking oil

loans.name: Georgette

texts.en:
Georgette was born in 1957 in Ouidah, a coastal town in Benin. For the past 25 years she has lived in Cotonou, Benin's largest city. She is married and has six children, all of whom are educated and two of whom are still dependent on their parents.

For the past 15 years, Georgette has run a stall from her home, where she sells various condiments and spices. She sources these from Tokpa, Benin's largest market situated in the heart of Cotonou. 

This is her third loan from 	Alidé following successful repayments in the past. It will enable Georgette to purchase additional stock, with the hope of strengthening her sales and growing her business.

loans.use: to purchase new stocks of spices and condiments

loans.name: Suymbek

texts.en:
Suymbek  K.  is 46 years old, married, and has five children. He has been engaged in breeding cattle since 2002, and today he has a farm with sheep, lambs and milk cows. Also, he and his wife cultivate cotton and, with the revenues from this activity, they have been able to pay for the education of their children.  They dream of seeing their son become one of the famous doctors of the country. 

Suymbek started this business with his first loan of 30,000 KGS and now manages to earn about 15,000 KGS monthly.  Suymbek plans to use this loan of 100,000 KGS to buy more sheep and cows. With the revenues, he wants to build a summer barn for his cattle. It will allow him to broaden his farm and make it more profitable.  In the future, Suymbek wants to buy a car and take his family for a vacation some day. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en:
Kenneth O. W. is 27 years old and married. He and his wife have one child, 8 months old, to whom they hope to give a good education to the university level. Kenneth's business is located in Kisumu, a region in Kenya known for fish production and Lake Victoria, commonly known as the lake basin.

Kenneth owns a motorcycle which he uses to provide transportation services to the local people in Kisumu. He has been in this business for three years and says that it is profitable. The major challenges he faces are financial constraints and the unavailability of some spare parts. However, he works very hard to keep his business going well. Kenneth is using his loan of KES 20,000 to buy spare parts to have his motorcycle serviced so he can provide better and more efficient customer service. He is a very hardworking man.

loans.use: to buy spare parts

loans.name: Ganiatou

texts.en:
Ganiatou is 34 years old and lives in the Sémé-Podji district of Cotonou, Benin's largest city. Together with her husband, Hervé, she looks after their four children who are all in school.

For the past seven years Ganiatou has been a travelling saleswoman, selling bolts of cloth which she sources from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. This is her third loan from ALIDE, following successful past repayments, and she will use it to increase her stock of cloth, with an aim to strengthen her sales figures.

loans.use: to purchase bolts of cloth

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a photo printer

loans.name: Mustapha

texts.en:
Mustapha is a 45-year-old married man living in Western Sierra Leone, near the town of Waterloo. He has four children, ranging in age from 3 to 13 years old, all of them currently attending school.

Mustapha has been running his general merchandise business for over 15 years now, and sells a wide range of rice, pepper, dried cassava, palm oil, and more food items. His main income comes from this business. He says his business is doing well right now. 

He has requested this loan to purchase more food items. He hopes to become a supplier to other shops in the future. He said that this loan will allow him to provide a good standard of living for his family.

loans.use: to purchase rice, pepper, dried cassava, and palm oil.

loans.name: Kandalat

texts.ru:
Кандалат Мамажанова родилась в городе Ош (Ошская область, Кыргызстан). Замужем и проживает с мужем, сыном, снохой и двумя внуками.
Кандалат родилась в 1953 году в простой и многодетной семье фермера. С раннего возраста помогала матери по дому и была самостоятельным ребенком. В 1972 году, после окончания школы, Кандалат поступила в Национальный университет на биологический факультет. В 1977 году, окончив обучение, Кандалат вернулась в город Ош и устроилась на работу в среднюю школу, в качестве учителя биологии. Став матерью двоих детей, она продолжала работать в школе, а супруг занимался полеводством.
В 1982 году Кандалат стала директором школы, где проработала до 2008 года. Из –за низкой оплаты, в 2008 году Кандалат решила оставить работу в школе, и вместе с семьей переезжают из Оша в село Новониколаевка (Чуйская область, Кыргызстан). Они покупают дом со всеми необходимыми хозяйственными постройками и участок земли в 3 гектара для выращивания фруктов и овощей. 
В данное время, благодаря упорству и трудолюбию Кандалат, в хозяйстве у нее имеется 1 дойная корова, 3 теленка и 1 бык, также ежегодно на своем участке в 3 гектара и на арендованных 14 гектарах, она выращивает фрукты, овощи, а также сажает зерновые культуры и клевер, необходимый для содержания собственного скота. Кандалат запрашивает кредит в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) для покупки семян арбуза, пшеницы, а также для покупки двух бычков для откорма. 
Со временем, Кандалат мечтает расширить площадь сарая, увеличить поголовье скота и купить благоустроенный дом в городе Карабалта (Чуйская область, Кыргызстан).
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.
texts.en:
Kandalat M. was born in the city of Osh (in the Osh region of Kyrgyzstan). She is married and lives with her husband, son, daughter-in-law, and two grandsons.

Kandalat was born in 1953 into a large and simple farm family. From an early age, she was an independent child who helped her mother with the house. In 1972 after leaving school, Kandalat entered the national university to study biology. In 1977, she graduated, returned to the city of Osh, and  got a job teaching biology in high school. She had two children and continued to work at school while her husband worked in agriculture. 

In 1982 Kandalat became the principal of the school, and she worked there until 2008. Because of the low salary, in 2008 Kandalat decided to quit and she and her family moved from Osh to the village of Novonikolaevka (in the Chuysky region in Kyrgyzstan). They bought a house and a three-hectare plot of land to grow fruit and vegetables.

At present, thanks to Kandalat’s persistence and diligence, their holdings include one milk cow, three calves, and one bull.  Additionally they grow fruit, vegetables, and the grain and clover to sustain their own cattle on their three hectares and fourteen hectares they rent. Kandalat is asking for a loan for 100,000 som (KGS) to buy watermelon seeds, wheat, and two calves for fattening. In time, Kandalat dreams of expanding their shed, increasing the number of livestock they own, and buying a nice house in the city of Karabalta (in the Chuysky region of Kyrgyzstan).

loans.use: to purchase seeds, wheat, and cattle.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses O. O. is 27 years old, single and does not have any children. His business is located in the busy Nyalenda area in Kisumu, a region in Kenya known for fish production and Lake Victoria, commonly known as the lake basin.

Moses owns a barber shop, where he provides hair cutting services to the local people in Kisumu. He has been in this business for one year and says that it is profitable. The major challenge he faces is lack of good shaving machines. However, he works very hard to keep his business going well. He is using his loan of KES 20,000 to buy shaving machines to provide better service to his customers, thus expanding the business. He hopes that in the future he will open a classic barbar shop in Kisumu. He describes himself as having good customer care.

loans.use: to buy shaving machines

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more motor vehicle spare parts

loans.name: Mwanahamisi

texts.en:
Mwanahamisi is a widow with one child who attends school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past three years, she has operated a firewood business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she also operates a coconut selling business, her other source of income. Mwanahamisi faces a major challenge of seasonality and high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of becoming self-reliant in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase bundles of firewood and sacks of coconuts for sale. Mwanahamisi decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of firewood and sacks of coconuts  for sale.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is 47 years old and married with two children, ages 16 years and 18 years. She runs a general merchandise shop in Waterloo in Sierra Leone.

She's been in this business for 10 years and sells rice, palm oil, dried cassava, pepper and more food stuff at Waterloo. She does not earn any other income except in this business. She does not have any challenges to her business.

Fatmata requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to buy more food stuffs. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to improve the standard of living of her family. She says that BRAC has been very helpful to her.

loans.use: to buy rice, palm oil, dried cassava, and pepper.

loans.name: Olive

texts.en: Olive is 33 years old and is married to a soldier. They do not have children yet. Olive is a tailor; she makes different styles from fabrics and is requesting a loan to buy traditional fabrics and thread for her tailoring business. She has done this business for three years, and with the profits, she wants to renovate their home.

loans.use: to buy traditional fabrics to sew clothing with.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Gaudance

texts.en: Gaudence is 31 and married, with 3 children between 2 and 13 years old. Two of her children are in school, and one is not old enough yet. Gaudence’s husband does not work. Gaudence owns a shop in which she sells rice, cooking oil, different kinds of flour, salt, tomatoes and beans. Gaudence started this business when she was 20 years old. Gaudence is requesting a loan to reinvest in her business, and with the profits, she will pay for her children’s school fees and feed her family.

loans.use: to reinvest in her business.

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. They own a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a vegetable stall.  She sells from home to her neighbors. She sells consumable goods on a daily basis, which helps her provide basic needs to her family. Mwanajuma faces a challenge of high transportation costs in her business. She dreams of becoming self-reliant in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase sacks of green vegetables, cabbage, kale, and coconuts for sale. She joined Yehu Microfinance to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of green vegetables, cabbage, kale and coconuts for sale.

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.es:
Alejandra forma parte del banco comunal “Mapuamulen” perteneciente a la ciudad de Concepción. Ella se dedica al rubro del comercio desde hace 5 años y vende frutas y verduras.
Alejandra trabaja en un local que adaptó en el patio de su casa, ella trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario continuado. Su mercadería la compra en la vega (centro comercial de verduras), ya que es más conveniente económicamente.  
Con el préstamo comprará frutas y verduras al por mayor.
Su sueño es tener un almacén, en el cual pueda vender abarrotes, artículos de aseo, verduras, entre otros. Además de comprar un automóvil que le permita trasladar su mercadería.  Respecto a sus sueños a nivel personal es poder postular a una vivienda propia, ya que en la actualidad Alejandra, su marido y sus cuatro hijos se encuentran viviendo en situación de allegados en la casa de sus suegros. Por lo que sus motivaciones de continuar en el negocio son específicamente para concretar sus sueños y aspiraciones, de ésta manera poder brindarle a su familia un mayor bienestar.
Alejandra está muy agradecida del préstamo otorgado por Fondo esperanza, ya que con éste podrá invertir en su negocio, él cuál le será fundamental. En relación a las reuniones Alejandra se siente muy contenta y cómoda. Además las relaciones interpersonales son muy gratas.
Y con las capacitaciones ha aprendido a distribuir y organizar de mejor manera sus ingresos generados por su negocio. 
Concepción, está asentada en la desembocadura del río Bíobío, uno de los más grandes del país, al sur de Chile, en la región del Bíobío. Ha tenido una importante función en nuestra historia, siendo sede de importantes batallas y asentamiento relevante, especialmente durante la Guerra de Arauco, por estar en la frontera con territorio mapuche. Actualmente la ciudad posee un importante desarrollo económico y demográfico, llegando a ser considerada como uno de los núcleos urbanos, demográfico, administrativo, financiero y comercial más relevantes de Chile, después de Santiago y Valparaíso.
texts.en:
Alejandra is a member of the community bank “Mapuamulen” from the city of Concepción. She has worked in trade for 5 years selling fruits and vegetables. 

Alejandra works her business from the courtyard in her home. She works everyday during the week on a fixed schedule. She buys her merchandise from the market (main center for vegetables), which is more economically convenient. 

With the loan she will buy fruits and vegetables in bulk. 

Her dream is to have a store where she can sell groceries, cleaning supplies, vegetables, among others, in addition to buying a car that will allow her to transfer the merchandise. 

On a personal level, her dream is to apply for homeownership because currently Alejandra, her husband and four children are living in a situation of close friends at the home of his in-laws. Therefore, their motivation to continue in the business is specifically to realize their dreams and aspirations, in this way to provide better welfare for their family.

Alejandra is very grateful for the loan granted by Fondo Esperanza, since with it she will be able to invest in her business, which will be fundamental. With respect to the meetings, Alejandra feels very happy and comfortable and the interpersonal relationships are very pleasant. With the training she has learned to distribute and better organize her business earnings.

Concepción sits at the mouth of the Bíobío river, one of the largest in the country, south of Chile, in the Bíobío region. It has had an important function in our history, being home to major battles and important settlement, especially during the War of Arauco, being on the border with Mapuche territory. Currently, the city has an important economic and demographic development, becoming considered as one of the urban, demographic, administrative, financial and most important commercial areas in Chile, after Santiago and Valparaiso.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Festus

texts.en: This is 43 year-old Festus.  He is married and has 2 children, aged 5 and 14 years. In 1998, Festus established his slipper and shoe business. He started because he wanted to be a responsible man and to provide adequately for his family.  Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about 300,000 from this business every month.  He would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,500,000. Festus requires a loan to buy different types and sizes of slippers and shoes. In the future, Festus plans to establish a similar business in another location for his wife.  He hopes to educate his children to university level. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more plastic slippers for his business

loans.name: Jacquline

texts.en: Jaqueline is 42 years old.   She has 5 children who are between the ages of 6 and 14 years.  She owns and runs a butcher shop.  She is requesting a loan to buy more cattle to slaughter.  She has done this business for 10 years and has been able to her pay her children's school fees and feed her family as well.  In the future, she plans to buy more cattle in order to sell both cattle and beef.

loans.use: to buy cattle for slaughtering.

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama is a widow with four school-aged children. They live at a house that they own.  It has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a firewood business.  She sells from home to her neighbors and passersby.  Salama not only operates a firewood business but also sells charcoal and coconuts, which contributes to her other source of income. She faces a challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of firewood, sacks of charcoal and coconuts for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of firewood, sacks of charcoal and coconuts for sale.

loans.name: Imad

texts.en:
Imad is a 31-year-old single man from Baalback.  He owns a shop where he sells Hookah (also known as a waterpipe) which is a single or multi-stemmed (often glass-based) instrument for smoking in which the smoke is cooled and filtered by passing through water. The tobacco smoked is referred to as narghile or shisha (sheesha) in the United Kingdom, United States and Canada. 

Originally from India, Hookah has gained popularity, especially in the Middle East, and is gaining popularity in North America, South America, Europe and Australia since 2001. Imad's business is expanding since the Hookah is expanding a lot in the region. Most of Imad's clients are friends, neighbors, relatives and some passing by. 

In addition to Hookah users, there are cafe owners who change their Hookahs continuously. Imad is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the second time, in order to increase his Hooka's inventory and to buy necessary household appliances. His previous loan was very efficient and it affected him positively, both socially and economically. He hopes to expand his business through starting a wholesale trade in the future.

loans.use: to increase his product inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 22-year-old single man from Lebanon. He is living with his parents. He started his career at a very young age working as a freelance home painter.  He cooperates with his father to provide better financial support for his family. He obtained his first Kiva loan and he was very satisfied with the results.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $2000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to renew his business tools and purchase paint for a new project. He needs to be prepared to serve the clients and make a good business reputation. In the future, he hopes to continue the growth of his profession and be able to take  on construction projects in order to expand his business operation.

loans.use: to renew his business tools and purchase paint.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
This is 33-year-old Ibrahim from Waterloo. He is married with three children between the ages of 8 years and 14 years. All three of the children attend school and Ibrahim also has one relative that he takes care of.

Ibrahim runs a general merchandise shop where he sells rice, dried cassava, pepper, benni seeds, and more food stuff. He has been running this business for 15 years. He has requested a loan in order to be a supplier to other shops. The extra income from this loan will allow him to improve the standard of living of his family.

loans.use: to buy rice, dried cassava, pepper, and benni seeds.

loans.name: Fandy

texts.en: This is 44 year-old Fandy.  She is married and has 3 children, aged 26, 24 and 20 years. In 1996, Fandy established her fish business. She began her business because she needed to have a source of income to help her take care of her family.  Working 6 days a week and 8 hours a day, she earns about Le 900,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000 in order to buy more fish to supply other traders. In the future, Fandy plans to be one of the leading fish agents who supplies other local women in her community.   She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more fish for her business

loans.name: Washingtone

texts.en:
Washingtone O. sells second-hand shoes as a primary business and in addition he also sells second-hand clothes in Gikomba open air market in Nairobi. He has been in this business for 12 years, and earns an income of 20,000 KES per month. He is 46 years old, married to Regina, and they have six children.   

He has never borrowed from any other MFI, and he learned about KADET LTD through a friend who is member of a group registered with KADET. He is applying for his first loan from KADET LTD, with which he plans to buy more stock of second-hand shoes.          

Washingtone intends to use the anticipated profit to save and pay school fees for his children. In the future he plans to grow his business so the can open another outlet.

loans.use: to add more stock of second hand shoes

loans.name: Asiago

texts.en:
Asiago is married with two children, aged three and eight years. He has been running a mixed farming business for six years in his native home of Kisii in South Rift Kenya. He sells his produce of milk, tea and bananas to the local market. He also runs a retail shop business, which adds to his farming income. Asiago has requested a loan of 45,000 KES from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, to enable him to acquire an additional dairy cow. He says the acquisition of the additional dairy cow will boost his dairy production and income hence the entire family's living standard.
Asiago says his main challenges as a farmer are insufficient funds to pay for farm inputs and fluctuating market prices which drive fear into farmers. He remains appreciative for Juhudi Kilimo's effort to support farmers in doing business.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Violeta

texts.es:
Violeta forma parte del banco comunal “Mapuamulen” perteneciente a la ciudad de Concepción. Ella se dedica al rubro de amasandería desde hace 3 años, específicamente venta de empanadas, pastel de choclo y pan amasado. Violeta sale a vender sus productos a trabajadores de comercio establecido y barcos que llegan a la zona costera. Sin embargo la venta de sus productos bajó éstas semanas, debido a las replicas de tsunami de Japón, ya que también afectó las costas chilenas, específicamente Dichato. 
Su horario es totalmente flexible, ya que ella maneja su tiempo laboral. Su mercadería la compra en distribuidoras. Recibe ayuda de su hijo, para el traslado de sus productos de amasandería y mercadería.
Con el préstamo comprará una congeladora, un horno pequeño e ingredientes para sus productos de amasandería.
Su sueño es tener una panadería, para trabajar desde su casa, además de una revolvedora de masas, ya que el resto de maquinarias las tiene, gracias a los créditos obtenidos por Fondo esperanza. Respecto a sus sueños a nivel personal, estos son obtener su vivienda propia, ya que en la actualidad se encuentra viviendo en una casa que obtuvo de la Municipalidad de Concepción, a causa del terremoto del 27 febrero del año 2010. Por lo que sus motivaciones de continuar en el negocio son específicamente para concretar sus sueños, de ésta manera poder brindarle a su familia un mejor bienestar.
Violeta está muy agradecida de los créditos otorgados por Fondo Esperanza, ya que estos le han servido para invertir en su negocio. Respecto a las capacitaciones ella está muy contenta, ya que ha aprendido a distribuir mejor sus ingresos. 
Concepción, está asentada en la desembocadura del río Bíobío, uno de los más grandes del país, al sur de Chile, en la región del Bíobío. Ha tenido una importante función en nuestra historia, siendo sede de importantes batallas y asentamiento relevante, especialmente durante la Guerra de Arauco, por estar en la frontera con territorio mapuche. Actualmente la ciudad posee un importante desarrollo económico y demográfico, llegando a ser considerada como uno de los núcleos urbanos, demográfico, administrativo, financiero y comercial más relevantes de Chile, después de Santiago y Valparaíso.
texts.en:
Violeta is a member of the communal bank “Mapuamulen” in the city of Concepción. She has been working as a baker for 3 years, specifically selling empanadas, corn cake, and kneaded bread. Violeta goes out and sells her products to commercial workers and ship workers who arrive in the coastal area. However her sales have dropped in the past few weeks due to the aftershocks of the tsunami in Japan, which also effected the Chilean coasts, specifically Dichato. Her schedule is totally flexible because she sets her own hours. She buys her merchandise from distributors. She receives help from her son, who moves her bakery products and merchandise.

With this loan she will buy a freezer, a small oven, and ingredients for her bakery products. Her dream is to have a bakery, work from home, and, additionally, to own a dough turner because she has the rest of the machines thanks to the loans she's received from Fondo esperanza. As far as her personal dreams, she's like to own her own home because at the moment she lives in a house that she got from the municipality of Concepción because of the earthquake of February 27, 2010. The realization of her dreams and offering her family better well being keep her motivated to work,

Violeta is very thankful for the credits she's received from Fondo Esperanza because they have helped her invest in her business. With respect to the training, she's very happy because she's learned how to better distribute her income.

Concepción is situated at the mouth of the Bíobío river, one of the biggest in the country, in the south of Chile, in the region of Bíobío. It has played an important role in the history of Chile, being the site of many important battles and relevant settlements, especially during the Arauco war because it's on the border with the Mapuche territory. Currently the city posses an important economic and demographic development, becoming known as one of the urban, demographic, administrative, financial and commercial centers in Chile, after Santiago and Valparaíso.

loans.use: to buy a freezer, small oven, and ingredients for her baked goods

loans.name: Toni

texts.en:
Toni is a 46-year-old married man living in Bekaa with his wife and two children. Since 1990, Toni has worked changing car oil and wheels.
