loans.name: María Cristina

texts.es: María Cristina P. de cuarenta y nueve años de edad vive con su esposo, su hijo y su mama en el departamento de San Vicente. Ella posee un puesto ubicado en una calle principal del mercado municipal de San Vicente el cual es muy concurrido por las personas del lugar, María Cristina es una vendedora de las más solicitada por los clientes pues la conocen por ser muy servicial y por supuesto por tener los mejores refrescos y diferentes productos a un buen precio; esto a motivado a María a solicitarle a INTEGRAL  un crédito para comprar más mercadería  como agua, frutas, azúcar, bolsas, golosinas entre otros; con esto espera satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes y al mismo tiempo cumplir una de sus metas hacer crecer su negocio y llevar a su hogar un solvento que les de seguridad económica a su familia.
texts.en:
María Cristina P., 49, lives with her husband, son and mother in San Vicente Department.  She has a stand in one of San Vicente’s Municipal Market’s main aisles that is quite heavily visited by local residents.

Maria Cristina is one of the most popular vendors because she’s known for being accommodating and, obviously, for having the best beverages and other products at the best prices.

This has motivated Maria to request a loan from INTEGRAL to buy more merchandise like water, fruit, sugar, bags and snacks, among others, to meet customer demand and at the same time reach one of her goals which is to make her business grow and provide her home with solvency that will give her family economic security.

loans.use: to buy water, fruit, sugar, bags and snacks.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Twenty-five year-old Ruth is a married woman with 2 young children. Her oldest child is only 2 years old.

Ruth is engaged in farming. She has been growing rice for 5 years. Her husband is also a farmer and mainly manages the farm. Ruth helps in preparing the land for crops. Like any other mother, Ruth wants her family to be happy and healthy always.

Ruth's loan will be used to purchase farm fertilizers and other supplies. In the future, Ruth hopes for a stable business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and other supplies

loans.name: Simprosa

texts.en:
Simprosa A. is from the village of Bocboc, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 59 years old. Simprosa is married and has two adult children. Simprosa owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, junk food, detergents, shampoo, soap & beverages in the local community. Simprosa has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2009, Simprosa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Simprosa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Simprosa is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, junk food & candies. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Simprosa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, junk food, & candies

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
Zubaida is 55 years old and married to K., who operates a sweetmeat selling business. His shop is located in the market and he sells variety of sweets at reasonable rates. He has been operating this business for the past 40 years. He has a good clientele base in his area who buy sweetmeat from him due to its good taste. 

Zubaida is a very supportive woman. She assists her husband financially by sewing clothes for her neighborhood clients. She receives regular orders from ladies in her community and fulfills them on time to earn an income. 

She lives in a small city called Borewala, in a two-room brick house with her family. Borewala is located in Punjab province of Pakistan and known for its wood works, like furniture. She has been living there for the past 50 years. 
She is the mother of a daughter and two sons. Her eldest son sells bread (by operating a tandoor, a kind of oven made of sand, and uses fire in it to make bread) while the others are studying at a local school. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the betterment of her son’s bread-selling business. With the loan, he will purchase flour and wood in larger quantities to prepare more bread and make more money. 

He has a number of years of experience in his business and Zubaida hopes that an investment will be a productive one for him. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Zubaida.

loans.use: to buy flour and firewood for bread-making

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en:
Jane T. is from the village of San Antonio, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 55 years old. Jane is the group leader of an 11-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Jane is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Jane owns & operates a tailoring business providing specialty tailoring services to local community members. Jane has been engaged in her business for over 18 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Jane joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Jane is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional cloth and sewing materials to provide better service. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Jane from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional cloth and sewing materials

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth, 56 years old, lives in Banga, South Cotabato, with her family. She is married and has 6 children. Her oldest child is 33 years old and the youngest is 17.

Ruth is a farmer and has been growing rice for over 25 years. Ruth works hard to keep the farm productive. She wants to be able to keep up with the increasing needs in her household.

Ruth currently needs fertilizers and seeds. She requested a loan so she could buy them.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Anwer's Group

texts.en:
Anwer is a resident of Borewala, which is a small city of Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. Her house is located in Habib colony, where she has been living with her family in a 2 room brick house for the past 15 years. 

Anwer sews dresses at her home for her neighborhood clients. She is very skillful in her work and receives regular orders every month.  Her husband’s name is T. M., and he has a construction supply business. He provides his services to different construction companies and individuals who come to buy construction supplies from him. Anwer has two daughters and a son. Her daughters are studying, while her son has a business of welding. 

Anwer has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, to buy another welding machine for her son’s business. This will help him do his work more effectively and provide better quality services to his clients. He will be able to hire an assistant who will help him in completing his work.   He has been doing this business for the past 14 years, and Anwer hopes that a loan will help him further improve his business.

Note: "In the photo, the lady with a raising hand is Anwer".

loans.use: to buy another welding machine for welding business

loans.name: Gingin

texts.en:
Gingin A. is from the village of Poblacion, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 42 years old. Gingin is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Gingin owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop selling snack foods, powder juices, canned goods, shampoo, soap, & candies in the local community. Gingin has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 13,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Gingin joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gingin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Gingin is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods & snack foods. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Gingin from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods & snack foods

loans.name: Sor

texts.en:
Sor S. is a 32-year-old woman who was divorced from her husband a few years ago. She lives with her three children in the province of Kompong Tom, and the children are enrolled in the local school.

Sor sells boiled corn in the market place. She usually generates an income of about 2.5 USD a day to help support the family in its expenses.

Sor is applying for a loan to buy more corn to boil for resale. Sor hopes this loan will help her earn additional profits so as to raise her family’s standard of living. She dreams of building a bigger house and having all of her children finish high school.

loans.use: To buy more corn to boil for resale

loans.name: Merilyn

texts.en:
Merilyn is 54 years old and married with five children. Merilyn works very hard to provide for them.

Merilyn runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell.

Merilyn has been in this business for 20 years and sells a variety of items such as biscuits, candies, etc.

In the future, Merilyn would like to expand her business and take care of family needs.

loans.use: to buy more stock for her general store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy corn, chicharrón (fried pork skin), cheese, beans, vegetables and oil.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna O. is from the village of West Kibawe, Kibawe, Bukidnon. She is 55 years old. Lorna is widowed and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Lorna owns & operates a business selling animal feed & farm-related products, like hog & rooster feed. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lorna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 21,000 PHP from HSPFI. The previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 26,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional sacks of hog & chicken feed. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Lorna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of hog & chicken feed

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley is a married woman from Banga, South Cotabato. She is 41 years old and has 2 children, aged 18 and 13.

Shirley started farming 3 years ago. She grows rice to sell to her community. Aside from rice farming, she also grows pigs and ducks, and runs a sari-sari store.

Shirley's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Dolores' Group

texts.en:
Dolores S. is from the village of Villa Concepcion, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 52 years old. Dolores is the group leader of a 13-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Dolores is married and has 6 adult children.  Dolores owns & operates a general store selling both food and products for daily use. Dolores has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Dolores joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dolores has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. The previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Dolores is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Dolores from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Norigen

texts.en:
Norigen E. is from the village of Kahulugan, Kimaya, Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old. Norigen is widowed and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Norigen owns & operates a specialized retail store selling green bananas & coconuts for copras in the local community. Norigen has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 14,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Norigen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norigen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 21,000 PHP from HSPFI. The previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Norigen is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional green and yellow bananas & coconuts. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Norigen from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional green and yellow bananas & coconuts

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma is 39 years old and married, with 3 children. Her oldest child is 16 years old and the youngest is only 5.

Thelma is engaged in farming. Her parents, who were also farmers, taught her how to farm. Now that she has her own family, she applied what she learned and invested in a rice farm. Thelma wants to invest in other kinds of businesses but, she said, she does not have the capital to start yet.

Thelma's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea B., age 49, is the mother of eight children, six of whom are single, while the other two are married and live independently. Her husband is a carpenter who works in their community building wooden houses.

Chea grows cashews on her farmland to raise money. She gets great results from her cashew plants almost every year and makes around 2 USD in profit each day. She is asking for a loan to hire a few domestic laborers to plow her land for her next cashew crop.

loans.use: To hire a few laborers to plow her land

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Van V. is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Van sells groceries, earning an income of USD 9 per day. Her husband is an electronics repairman, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 50 on food and USD 30 on the other necessary expenses. Van is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner. V. appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: to buy a truck to transport agriculture products to resell

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy D. is from the village of Salay in Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old. Juvy is married and has two school-age children. To make a living, Juvy owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling coconuts for copras and for making coco charcoal in the local community. Juvy has been engaged in her business for over six years, and she earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Juvy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juvy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Juvy is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional coconuts for copras and charcoal. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Juvy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional coconuts for copras and charcoal

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is 39 years old. She is married and has three children. Her oldest child is 13 years old. Vilma has been engaged in farming for five years. She grows rice to sell in her community. Vilma also started a sari-sari store to add income for her family.

Vilma requested this loan to buy seeds and fertilizer. She hopes to have a better harvest. Vilma also wishes for her children to finish college and to have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Pov's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of 12 members. Mrs. Pov was born in 1967 and is a village bank president. She was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. Each member of this village will use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Pov and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land they use to grow rice for their family's living expenses. With this farm, they do not have enough money to support it. Thus, Mrs. Pov would like to ask for a loan to buy a water machine, fertilizers and pesticide for growing rice. Aside from farming, they also earn for their family by fishing.

This couple has four children: Three are attending the local school and the youngest one is 3 years old.

loans.use: to buy a water machine, fertilizers and pesticide for growing rice

loans.name: Kruy

texts.en:
Kruy K. is 27 years of age and a married woman. Her husband and she have been married for years, but they don’t have a baby yet.

In order to attend to the couple’s needs, Kruy runs a small market, and the items which she always sells out of are such things as soft drinks, fast food, plastic products, and cooking ingredients. She has been in business for over one year and is earning approximately 2.5 USD per day. Her husband sells ice cream in and around his community.

Kruy hopes to enlarge her business and is applying for a loan to be used to accumulate a larger number of items to sell. This will allow her to increase her income and upgrade the couple’s living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a larger number of items to sell

loans.name: Sin's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sin was born in 1964. She and her husband are farmers who rent a one-hectare plot of land upon which they grow rice and bananas to sell. This couple is working hard on their farm to support their four children, three of whom are construction workers and the last, a student in the local school.

Mrs. Sin is the village’s bank president. She was selected to be the president by the other thirteen members of the group. While the members of this village group will use their portions to support their different purposes, the group will be responsible for any member who might default on his or her loan.

In order to better her farm’s production, Mrs. Sin is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides and to hire laborers to plow her field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides, to pay for hire laborers to plow her farming field.

loans.name: Amraa

texts.en: Amraa, age 41, is widowed and lives with her daughter in Uvurhangai Province in Mongolia. They live in a ger (a Mongolian nomadic housing tent) on a small plot of land that they have owned for the past ten years. They have a decent standard of living. Amraa started working as a salesperson at a stall in 2004, and she began operating her own construction materials trading business in 2008. Now, she sells construction materials from a store that she owns, and her current retail turnover exceeds 7,000,000 MNT. She is a hardworking and polite person. Amraa is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to purchase more construction materials for her business.

loans.use: to purchase more construction materials

loans.name: Lanh's Group

texts.en:
There are five people who formed a group loan. Mrs. Lanh was born in 1968 and is the group leader. She was selected to be the group leader by the other members. The members of this group will use their money to help support their different purposes. 

Lanh's husband is a wedding chef who is able to earn a small income to support his family. He also earns a living as a motorcycle taxi driver. This couple has five children: two are wedding chefs who support their father carriers and the others three are students and also help their parents businesses. 

Mrs. Lanh earns her living by selling baby shell. Because her house is getting old for those living in it, Mrs. Lanh wants to fix it up. Thus, Lanh would like to ask for a loan to add to her savings for fixing her house up for better family living.

loans.use: To fix her house up for better family living.

loans.name: Juvencia

texts.en:
Juvencia B., age 58, owns and operates a general store, where she buys and sells such items as canned goods, snack foods, shampoo, soap, and biscuits to members of the local community. In addition, her store offers plastic basins, rope by the meter, and gasoline by the liter. Juvencia has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month. She is from the village of Pelaez, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She and her husband have three grown children.
 
In 2008, Juvencia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Juvencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and was employed as working capital. Juvencia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional rope and gasoline to offer for sale in her store. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Juvencia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional rope and gasoline to offer for sale in her store

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia A. is from the village of Poblacion in the municipality of Salay in Misamis Oriental Province. She is 54 years old. Cecilia is married, and she has five grown children. To make a living, Cecilia owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling seafood products, including fish such as sardines and mackerel in the local community. Cecilia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 9000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Cecilia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Cecilia is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish, such as mackerel and salmon. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Cecilia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish, such as mackerel and salmon

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma C., age 30, buys and sells dressed chicken in her local community. Alma has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. She is from the village of Aplaya, Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She and her husband have three school-aged children.

In 2008, Alma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and was employed as working capital. Alma is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional dressed chickens as well as hotdogs to offer for sale. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Alma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional dressed chickens as well as hotdogs to offer for sale

loans.name: Consuelo's Group

texts.en:
Consuelo S. is from the village of Linglingay, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 46 years old. Consuelo is the group leader of a 21-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Consuelo is married. To make a living, Consuelo owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Consuelo has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP every three months.

In 2011, Consuelo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Consuelo is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa J. is from the village of Aplaya, Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She is 31 years old. Marissa is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Marissa owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food in the local community. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling snacks & other delicacies like elbow macaroni and pork chicharon. Marissa has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 12000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marissa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marissa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients and fund working capital. Marissa is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients like pork and elbow macaroni. This loan will be her 6th loan from HSPFI.  Marissa plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food for sale

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda A. is from the village of Aplaya, Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She is 28 years old. Melinda is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Melinda owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods,  shampoo, soap and beverages in the local community. Melinda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 9000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Melinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital. 

Melinda is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods & snack foods. This loan will be her 7th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase food items to sell in her shop

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida L. is a 55-year-old married woman living in Trinidad, Bohol.  Adelaida runs a retail business and has been in this business for quite a long time now. She sells clothes, slippers and kitchenware in her community. This business earns for her 2,000 PHP per month. 

Adelaida is asking for a loan to buy clothes to resell.  This loan will help her continue her business.  In the future, Adelaida hopes to be able to send her 4 children to school and support the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: to purchase clothes to resell

loans.name: Rustam

texts.ru: Нуралиев Рустам житель города Турсунзаде. Ему 30 лет. Он женат. Имеет 6 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Рустам имеет среднее образование. У него имеется хлебопекарня. Он в основном печет и продает в оптом хлеб. В этом ему помогает жена. Он берет кредит для покупки муки, чтобы производить больше хлеба и расширит свою деятельность.
texts.en: Rustam N. lives in the town of Tursun-zoda. He is 30 years old. He is married and has six children. His wife is a homemaker. Rustam has secondary education and he owns a bakery. He mainly bakes bread and sells it wholesale. His wife is also helping him. He is taking out the loan to buy flour to make more bread and expand his business.

loans.use: to buy flour

loans.name: Edamire

texts.en:
Edamire P. is from the village of Santa Cruz, Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old. Edamire is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Edamire owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, biscuits, shampoos, soaps and beverages in the local community. She also sells coconuts and bananas. Edamire has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 16000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Edamire joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and to fund working capital for her business. 

Edamire is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional bananas, coconuts and canned goods to sell. This loan will be her 10th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to stock bananas, coconuts and some  goods to sell

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is currently in the business of selling drugs in her clinic.  She is 25 years old, married to a doctor, and has 2 children who are both attending school.  Esther borrowed a loan to stock more drugs to sell. She hopes to expand with the extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: stock more drugs to sell

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet M. operates a retail shop in Kawangware market in Nairobi, and besides that, she runs a cyber café  which she just  opened recently . She has been in the retail business for four years and earns an income KES. 30,000 per month.  She is a married lady with two children, and she is 26 years old.     


She has never borrowed from any other MFI, and she learned about KADET LTD through a friend who is member of a group registered with KADET. She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD. She intends to use the entire loan amount to add stock to the shop and buy a computer for the cyber café.           


Janet intends to use the anticipated profit to save and pay school fees for her children. In the future she plans to grow her business and establish a big shop.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her shop and one computer for the cyber cafe

loans.name: Gulnora

texts.ru: Рачабова Гулнора проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 46 лет. Замужем, имеет троих детей. Муж работает в заводе алюминия. Сама Гулнора занимается торговлей на рынке. Она в основном продает фрукты. Этим видом деятельности занимается 15 лет. Кредит берет для покупки апельсинов. Она хочет увеличить ассортимент своего товара.
texts.en: Gulnora R. lives in the town of Tursun-zoda. She is 46 years old. She is married and has three children. Her husband works in the aluminum factory. Gulnora sells on the market. She sells mainly fruits and has been in this business for fifteen years. She is taking out the loan to buy oranges and wants to increase the variety of her produce.

loans.use: to buy oranges

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Pedro D. is from the village of Canabuan Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 52 years old. Pedro is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Pedro plants and harvests rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over 25 years and earns approximately 35,000 PHP every harvest season (or after 5 months).

In 2011, Pedro joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 8000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This is Pedro's first loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchase fertilizer for his rice farm

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy K. owns and operates a bar business. She has been in this business for ten years, and she works seven days a week. Teddy has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more crates of beer and jerycans of local gin to offer to her customers. The main business challenges for Teddy are thieves and defaulters. 

Teddy and her husband live in the Nakulabye neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda, in a home that they own. They have two children, one of whom is enrolled in school, and Teddy also cares for additional family members. The family has access to electricity and to piped water.

loans.use: to buy more crates of beer and jerycans of local gin to offer to her bar customers

loans.name: Florencio

texts.en:
Florencio, age 48, is a rice farmer in Trinidad, Bohol. He sells his harvested rice to members of his community. He and his wife have five children. Florencio works hard to improve his business and his family's living conditions. He is currently making improvements to their house. He also hopes to be able to sustain his children's education. 

Florencio's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and farm equipment, such as a new plow. He hopes to earn a better income from his next harvest so that he can complete the family house.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and farm equipment, such as a new plow

loans.name: Randy

texts.en:
Randy L., age 31, is a rice farmer. He offers his harvested rice for sale to members of his community. Randy has been engaged in his business for over eight years and earns approximately 27,000 PHP per harvest. Randy is from the village of Canabuan Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. He and his wife have three school-aged children. 
 
Randy has just joined ASKI in hopes of gaining access to financial services. He wants to help improve his living situation and increase his ability to engage in business activities. Randy is requesting his first loan from ASKI in the amount of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Ruth has requested a loan in order to stock more sugar to offer for sale. She hopes eventually to expand her business with the extra profits.

loans.use: to stock more sugar to offer for sale

loans.name: Nul

texts.en:
Nul R., age 40, is a tailor. She earns an income of USD 3.33 per day through her business. She needs to earn more in order to support her family, since they must spend USD 44 on food and USD 45 on the other necessaR. expenses eveR. month. 

For this reason, R. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to start a new business. With the loan, she will buy groceR. items to offer for sale in a new groceR. business. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair the family house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

Nul R. resides in Prey Veng province, Cambodia, an area known as one of the largest rice producing regions in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy grocery items to offer for sale in a new grocery business

Junior is requesting his first loan from ASKI in the amount of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

However, each month the famiL. has to spend USD 30 on food and USD 45 on the other necessary expenses. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair the famiL. house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.name: Ngoun

texts.en: Ngoun S. is 27 years old.  She resides in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for its rubber plantations. S. is a tailor, earning an income of USD 7 per day. loans.name: Otgonkhishig

texts.en:
Otgonkhishig is 25 years old.  She lives with her husband and 9-month-old daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, on her father’s plot of land. Her husband helps in her business. 

Otgonkhishig used to be a salesperson in an outdoor market selling different type of sunglasses and gained much experience over the years. In 2006, she decided to run her own sunglasses retail business. 

Otgonkhishig is a very helpful and hardworking person.  She is planning to rent out a toy car at the children’s playground, charging 40 cents for 3 minutes. She is asking for a loan to buy a toy car from China to start this business and also to buy more sunglasses to sell.

loans.use: stock more sunglasses to sell and also to start a new playground business

loans.name: Khem

texts.en:
Khem V. is 30 years old.  She lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for its rubber plantations. V. is a farmer and also a food vendor, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband has a job transporting fruit juice, earning an income of USD 8 per day. Each month, the family must spend USD 75 on food and USD 25 on other necessary expenses. 

V. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more ingredients to expand her food selling business. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner. V. appears in the photograph while she is selling her food to her customers.

loans.use: purchase ingredients for her food selling business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase the variety of merchandise

loans.name: Tuya

texts.en:
Tuya, 49, is married and lives with her husband and a daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small rented plot of land. 

Tuya began selling clothes at Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in the city, in 1999. Her monthly sales range up to 1,900,000 MNT and her current working capital exceeds 800,000 MNT, in addition to her inventory. She pays 36,000 MNT for the monthly rent of the stall. She goes to China to purchase consumer goods once or twice a month depending on her sales volume. 

Tuya is a responsible and modest person who says, "we want to build a house where we can have a comfortable life in the future". She is requesting a loan of 1,700,000 MNT to purchase more consumer goods for her business.

loans.use: purchase more consumer goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 35-year-old Lebanese married woman. She lives with her husband and two young children, who are still attending school. She has been producing plastic agricultural tents for 8 years. In 2008, she bought her own land and started cultivating different types of vegetables according to the season. She uses her plastic tents to grow her produce faster. She distributes the harvest to specific agricultural markets that she deals with. She is thankful for her business; it allows her to make extra money for the family.

Today, she is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to buy new farming products and supplies such as fertilizers and seeds, because she's planning to expand her business. She is certain that the loan will help her increase her productivity and therefore her sales.

loans.use: to buy new farming products and supplies.

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en:
Reynaldo G. is from the village of Canabuan Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 44 years old and is married. To make a living, Reynaldo plants and harvests rice for sale. Reynaldo has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2011, Reynaldo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 10000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This will be Reynaldo's first loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: purchase fertilizer for his rice farm

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza has been a fish vendor for nine years. She buys her fish directly from fishermen and sells an assortment of fresh fish from her rented stall at the local market. 

Analiza has requested this loan in order to purchase more fish to offer for sale at market. 

Analiza and her husband have one child. In the future, she hopes for her child to finish college and attain success.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to offer for sale at market

loans.name: Normurod

texts.ru: Гулямгусейнов Нормурод проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 24 года. Женат. Имеет одного ребенка. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Нормурод занимается торговлей. Он арендует торговую точку, где продает метровые ленточки. Этим видом деятельности занимается 6 лет. Кредит берет для покупки метровых ленточек и новых материалов.
texts.en: Normurod G. lives in Tursun-zoda. He is 24 years old, married, and has one child. His wife is a housewife. Normurod works in trade. He rents a shop where he sells lengths of tape. He has been doing this work for six years.  He is taking out a loan to buy more tape and new materials.

loans.use: to buy lengths of tape and new materials

loans.name: Timoteo

texts.en:
Timoteo P., age 49, tends and raises livestock. He raises pigs for fattening and sale. Timoteo has been engaged in his business for over seven years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP every four months. He is from the village of Baracbac Sta. Fe, Nueva Vizcaya. He and his wife have four school-aged children. 
 
Timoteo has just recently joined ASKI in the hopes of gaining access to financial services. He wants to help improve his family's living situation and increase his ability to engage in business activities. Timoteo is requesting his first loan from ASKI in the amount of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Bayanjargal

texts.en: Bayanjargal, 21, is single and lives with his mother and his siblings in Zavhan province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land. His mother is unemployed. One of his brothers attends a college, while the other two brothers attend a local secondary school and a kindergarden respectively. Bayanjargal began driving a taxi in 2006. His father passed away last year, and he is now responsible for his family. He is a hardworking and modest person. He says, "I am the one who is responsible for the family now. My father was a driver and mechanic. From now on, I will continue his work, as I learned a lot from him. I am trying hard to increase my profit because I will pay the tuition fees of my brothers and repay the bank loans." He is requesting a loan of 500,000 MNT to purchase spare parts for his car.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts

loans.name: Wassa Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Wassa, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 48 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wakoro, préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de tubercules, de condiments et de galettes.                                                                                                                    
Les femmes du groupe Wassa sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire.                                                                           
DIPA D. compte acheter beaucoup de tubercules avec les revendeurs au niveau du marché de Nangola. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement au village de Wakoro, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 40 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité.
texts.en:
The Wassa group is made up of married women, each with an average age of 48 and 4 children. They live in extended traditional families in the village of Wakoro, in the Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). 
They know each other through blood and neighborhood ties, as well as existing friendships.They are in the business of selling tubers, condiments and cakes. 
The women of the Wassa group are on their second loan. 
DIPA D. is planning on buying a lot of tubers from the sellers at the market in Nangola. She makes her sales daily in the village of Wakoro, for cash and on credit to a clientele of men and women. 
She plans to make a monthly profit of 40 000F CFA which will be used to pay for her installments and to make contributions to social ceremonies. The rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy tubers

loans.name: Willima

texts.en: H. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes. She is 33 years old, married to a businessman, and has six children who go to school. H. borrowed a loan to stock more tomatoes to sell. With the extra profits from her business, she hopes to expand the business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more tomatoes to sell.

loans.name: Vy

texts.en: Vy C., 24, resides in Battambong province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. C. operates a beauty salon, earning an income of 6 USD per day. Each month, her family has to spend 45 USD on food and 25 USD on other necessary expenses. C. is requesting a loan of 1200 USD to purchase more products to expand the offerings at her beauty salon. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more products for her beauty salon

loans.name: Herminio

texts.en:
Herminio B., age 56, is a rice farmer. He offers his harvested rice for sale to members of his community. He has been engaged in his business for over 28 years and earns approximately 33,000 per harvest. He is from the village of Canabuan Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. He and his wife have five school-aged children. 

Herminio has just receny joined ASKI in hopes of gaining access to financial services. He hopes to help improve his living situation and increase his ability to engage in business activities. Herminio is requesting his first loan from ASKI in the amount of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure for use in his rice field

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis M. is 36 years old and single. He is from the village of Canabuan within Aritao municipality, a part of Nueva Vizcaya province on the islands of Luzon. Francis is a farmer who plants and harvests rice for sale. Francis has been in business for over ten years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP every harvest season.

In 2011, Francis joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. He is requesting a loan, his first from ASKI, of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace N. is a sole proprietor business lady, who runs a restaurant in Karen; Nairobi. She has been in this business for one year, and earns an income of KES. 40,000 per month. She is 49 years old, single and a mother one child who is six years old.    


She has never borrowed from any other MFI, and she learned about KADET LTD through a friend. She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD. She intends to use the entire loan amount to improve the interior decor of the restaurant by buying modern furniture.            


Grace intends to use the anticipated profit to save and to grow the business to a capital base of one million in the next five years.

loans.use: to buy modern furniture for her restaurant.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita is 51 years old and married with eight children.

Nenita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 29,500 loan through NWTF to buy more stock.

Nenita has borrowed and paid back 14 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 15 years and also earns an income from buying and selling charcoal.

Nenita aspires to have her children finish their education and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Svay

texts.en:
Svay S., 32, resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. S. is a farmer, earning an income of $2.50 per day. Her husband purchases cows to resell, earning an income of $6 per day. 

Each month, the family has to spend $35 on food and $50 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase cows to resell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy cows to resell

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 41 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wakoro, préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce d’articles divers.                                                                                                                          
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des fruits, des condiments, des articles divers de boutique et des céréales.                                                                          
MAFOU B. compte acheter des fruits avec les revendeurs du village. Elle effectue ses ventes à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  40 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce de fruits.
texts.en:
All married, the women of the Benkadi group average 41 years of age and 4 children. They live in extended traditional families in the village of Wakoro, in the Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).
They know each other through blood and neighborhood ties, as well as existing friendships. They sell miscellaneous items.
The women of the Benkadi group are on their third loan, which will be used to buy fruits, condiments, various shop items, and cereal.
MAFOU B. is planning on buying fruits from the sellers in the village. She makes her sales from her home and at the market, for cash and on credit, to a clientele of men and women.
She plans to make a monthly profit of 40 000F CFA which will be used to pay for her installments and make contributions to social ceremonies. The rest will be reinvested in her fruit business.

loans.use: To buy fruits

loans.name: Kea

texts.en:
Kea H., 32, resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. Kun is a farmer and raises pigs, earning an income of $3 per day. Her husband sells wood, earning an income of $5 per day. 

Each month, the family has to spend $30 on food and $50 on the other necessary expenses. H. is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase cows to resell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy cows to resell

loans.name: Ibuka Group

texts.fr:
Rose N.  est une  vieille commerçante âgée de 61 ans qui habite  la commune  de Nyanza-Lac en province de Makamba au Sud du Burundi. Elle fait le commerce de produits alimentaires comme les bananes, le manioc et l’huile de palme. Elle exerce ce métier depuis 5 ans mais vendait la bière avant. Elle n’a  pas fréquenté l’école. Elle est veuve avec 5 enfants dont 3 d’entre eux déjà maries. Ils sont tous adultes et aucun d’eux reste encore à l’école. Elle arrive au 4e cycle dans le crédit Communautaire avec Turame. 

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter son capital en achetant une grande quantité de produits alimentaires  à revendre pour réaliser de grands bénéfices. Elle espère que ce métier lui permettra de subvenir a ses besoins même en son âge avance.

Elle est membre  du groupe  Communautaire« Ibuka».
texts.en:
Rose N. is a 61-year-old merchant who lives in the town of Nyanza-Lac, province of  Makamba, in southern Burundi. She is a member of the Ibuka solidarity group. She is a widow with five children, three of whom are already married. They are all adults who no longer go to school. She herself never attended school. 

She sells food items such as bananas, cassava, and palm oil, and has five years of experience in this business. Prior to her current activity, she used to sell beer. She has reached her fourth loan cycle with Turame.

She turned to Kiva for a loan to increase her working capital. She will buy a large quantity of food for resale in order to make substantial profits. 

She hopes that this activity will allow her to support herself despite her age.

loans.use: to buy a large quantity of food items for resale

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Thirty-two-year-old Analiza earns a living through rice farming. She started her business five years ago. She tills her land and prepares it well for the crops. Part of her harvest is for family consumption, and she sells the rest to the market. 

Analiza has requested a loan to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

Analiza is married and has five children. Her oldest child is 10 years old while the youngest is only 2. Analiza wishes to improve their house and for her children to finish college in the future.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Bashir

texts.en:
Bashir H. O. is 31 years old, single and does not have any children yet. He owns an auto spares shop serving mostly local car owners. Besides selling spare parts, he is also a mechanic and repairs and services vehicles. His business is located in Jua Kali, Kisumu, at a car yard. Kisumu is the region in Kenya known for the production of fish. It harbours Lake Victoria and is commonly known as the lake basin. 

Bashir has been in his business for four years now. He says that his business is profitable and the major challenge he has is the unavailability of certain spare parts which, if found, are expensive. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings to buy spare parts to grow his business and meet the demands of his customers. He hopes to grow his business and get tenders to service corporate vehicles. He also sees himself having his own family. He describes himself as jovial and understanding.

loans.use: to buy spare parts.

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkan, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 45 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wakoro, préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de beurre de karité, de condiments, de tubercules, de l’arachide et de l’habillement.  Les femmes du groupe Benkan sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursé le premier.                                                                                                                                                                                                  
SEBA C. compte acheter beaucoup de noix de karité avec les revendeurs du village ; qu’elle transforme en beurre de karité. Après transformation, elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement à la maison et au marché de Wakoro, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour prendre en charge les dépenses liées à l’entretient de sa famille et le reste pour consolider d’avantage son activité de commerce de beurre de karité.
texts.en: The women of the group Benkan are all married and average 45 years of age and four children. The women all live in traditional extended families in the village of Wakoro, prefecture of Dioïla, Region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of kinship, community, and friendship. They do commerce in karité butter, condiments, tubers, peanuts, and clothing. And they are on their second solidarity loan after having properly repaid the first one. Ms. Seba C. intends to use her loan to buy a lot of karité nuts from village retailers. She processes the nuts into karité butter. Then, at the house and at the Wakoro market, she makes her sales every day, accepting cash or credit from a customer base composed of women and men. Seba envisions making an average monthly profit of 10,000 francs CFA that will be used to cover the costs associated with caring for the family. The rest of the profits will be used for consolidating further her butter business.

loans.use: to buy karité nuts

loans.name: Carlito

texts.en:
Carlito is a married man with four children. He lives in Trinidad, Bohol, with his family. He owns and manages a sari-sari (variety) store there. Carlito sells assorted products that his neighbors and other people in his community regularly buy from him.

Carlito is requesting a loan of 16,000 Philippines pesos to purchase canned goods, soft drinks and other merchandise to sell.

Carlito works hard to improve his business and sustain his children's education.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, soft drinks and other merchandise to sell
